name: Tiagabine
summary: Tiagabine (Gabitril) is an anticonvulsant used as adjunctive therapy for partial seizures.
description: Tiagabine, marketed under the brand name Gabitril, is an antiepileptic drug primarily indicated as adjunctive therapy for partial seizures in patients with epilepsy. It works by inhibiting the reuptake of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) into presynaptic neurons and glial cells, thereby increasing the availability of GABA in the synaptic cleft and enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission. Tiagabine is not typically used as monotherapy and is associated with a risk of provoking seizures in individuals without epilepsy or when used off-label for non-epileptic conditions.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to tiagabine or formulation components

items: Adjunctive treatment of partial seizures in epilepsy

sections.text: Inhibits GABA reuptake into presynaptic neurons and glial cells by blocking the GABA transporter-1 (GAT-1), thereby increasing extracellular GABA concentrations and enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission.

adult.oral: Initial: 4 mg once daily; increase by 4–8 mg/day at weekly intervals; usual maintenance: 32–56 mg/day divided into 2–4 doses; maximum: 56 mg/day.

pediatric.oral: Safety and efficacy not established for patients under 12 years.

sections.text: Steady-state plasma concentrations are reached within a few days; seizure control benefits may be observed within 1–2 weeks.

other: May induce seizures in patients without epilepsy
Monitor for mood changes and suicidal ideation

sections.pregnancy: Limited human data; use only if potential benefit justifies potential risk
sections.lactation: Unknown excretion in human milk; use caution
sections.geriatrics: Increased sensitivity possible; start at low dose

sections.text: Gradually reduce dose over at least 2–4 weeks to minimize seizure risk.

items: Not effective for generalized seizures; may worsen them
Should be used only in confirmed epilepsy cases
Caution with off-label psychiatric uses due to seizure risk
